I.   INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam has requested advisory technical assistance (TA) from the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) for Supporting Financial Management Decentralization.1 The 
Fact-Finding  Mission, 2 conducted  in  October  2007,  reached  an  understanding  with  the 
Government on the objectives, scope, financing plan, implementation arrangements, and terms 
of  reference  of  the  consultants  for  the  TA.  The  TA  will  focus  on  supporting  financial 
decentralization and improving local authorities’ financial management of projects financed by 
official  development  assistance  (ODA).  The  TA  is  included  in  ADB’s  2007–2010  country 
strategy and program for Viet Nam as a firm 2007 TA, and is based on the paper’s governance 
strategy  including  support  to  decentralization  issues  and  operational  priority  to  facilitate 
improved portfolio performance.3 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Over the past decade Viet Nam has steadily strengthened the framework and institutions 
for budget planning and execution. The new legal framework for public financial management is 
provided in the 2002 State Budget Law. It introduced several reforms such as clarifying powers 
and responsibilities, enhancing decentralization, and promoting transparency and accountability 
in public finance. The law also grants more authority to subnational governments for budget 
planning and management. The provincial people’s councils took over real powers in the budget 
approval  process.  From  1992  to  2002,  the  share  of  subnational  governments  in  total 
expenditure increased from 26% to 48%. The increased responsibilities and power for local 
governments created an urgent need to enhance the capacity of local institutions such as 
departments of finance, planning and investment, and treasury in public financial management.  
 
3.  Investment financed by the national budget has grown rapidly and is now about 40% of 
the  total  investment  in  the  country.  ODA  continues  to  play  an  important  role  in  public 
investment.  By  2006,  five  leading  development  partners:  ADB,  Agence  Française  de 
Développement, Japan Bank for International Cooperation, KfW Entwicklungsbank, and World 
Bank (i.e., the Five Banks) committed $19 billion to support Viet Nam’s development needs. The 
Government’s new Socio-Economic Development Plan 2006–2010 calls for a large increase in 
investment, particularly for infrastructure development. To achieve the plan’s goals to attain an 
average annual economic growth rate of 7.5%–8%, the total investment required is estimated at 
$140–$160 billion. To achieve this, $11 billion of ODA will need to be disbursed during 2006–
2010.  However,  disbursement  of  ODA  funds  is  slow  due  to  project  start-up  delay,  slow 
recruitment of consultants, and prolonged procurement. Limited financial management capacity 
at various levels continues to be cited as a factor that impedes project implementation and 
management.  
 
4.  With  growing  infrastructure  needs  and  a  greater  role  for  provincial  authorities  in 
economic development, provincial and municipal authorities tend to borrow directly from the 
domestic capital market and development agencies to finance their capital expenditure needs. 
For  example,  ADB,  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation,  and  World  Bank  are  now 
processing projects directly for Ho Chi Minh City. ADB has a number of pipeline projects to be 
implemented by the people’s committees of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, for which direct

lending is likely to be adopted. However the procedures and capacity of the local departments of 
finance in managing fund borrowing and repayment have not been comprehensively assessed. 
The recent update of Public Financial Management Accountability4 noted limited capacity of the 
local finance departments. Improved institutional arrangements, policy, and capacity for fund 
management are critically needed for local authorities to undertake borrowing. 
 
5.  The Government’s commitment to continued improvement of the legal and institutional 
framework for ODA management is an important factor for effective mobilization and utilization 
of ODA funds. Several decrees and regulations have been issued and revised. In 2006, the 
Government issued Decree 131/2006/ND/CP on ODA Management and Utilization. It facilitates 
greater decentralization of project management by allowing line ministries and/or provinces to 
appraise  and  approve  ODA  projects.  This  delegation  is  consistent  with  the  overall 
decentralization strategy of the Government with regard to investment from domestic resources. 
This change is expected to reduce the time required for investment decisions and accelerate the 
implementation of ODA programs and projects. One of the important reforms under Decree 131 
is the emphasis on transparency and dissemination of information related to ODA priorities, 
policies,  and  procedures.  The  decree  introduces  a  clearer  system  for  monitoring  project 
performance. Despite these changes, impediments have been encountered in implementing 
decentralized projects. Review and approval of the work plan, procurement, financial plan, and 
budget changes have to go through different levels of authorities; this exerts an unnecessary 
administrative burden on the project management units and delays project implementation. 
Management procedures for decentralized projects need to be streamlined. 
 
6.  Decree  131/2006/ND-CP  stipulates  that  ODA  programs  and  projects  should  be 
implemented  in  accordance  with  the  related  legal  documents  for  domestic  programs  and 
projects in terms of appraisal and approval, procurement, settlement and site clearance, taxes, 
etc. In accordance with the Hanoi Core Statement on Aid Effectiveness, this provides a good 
opportunity for aligning funding agency procedures with the Government system, as it is being 
strengthened to reflect international standards and practices.  
 
7.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) issued implementing guidelines on financial management 
of ODA projects under Decree 131, specifying procedures for financial planning and approval of 
the financial plan, disbursement of ODA funds, and control of expenditures. The implementing 
guidelines are cross-referenced to other legal documents governing different aspects of public 
financial management such as those on accounting, auditing, taxation, and preparation of final 
accounts.  Training  of  staff—local  staff  in  particular—is  needed  on  the  new  policies  and 
procedures for financial management of ODA projects. The 2007 Joint Portfolio Performance 
Review conducted by the Government’s Inter-Ministerial Task Force on ODA and the Five 
Banks (para. 3) suggests that as more power and authority are delegated to line ministries and 
local  authorities,  the  need  to  enhance  their  capacity  to  effectively  assume  the  increased 
responsibilities  will  become  critical.  The  TA  for  enhancing  ODA  absorptive  capacity  and 
efficiency approved in October 2007 was designed to help the Government implement the 
specific actions recommended by this review that are expected to improve performance of the 
ODA portfolio.5

8.  The 2007–2010 country strategy and program considers improved governance, greater 
efforts to control corruption, and ADB assistance to these areas as key for ADB inventions in 
Viet Nam over the next 3 years (footnote 3). It states that with 40% of gross domestic product to 
be devoted to investment each year (as envisaged in the Socio-Economic Development Plan), 
mobilizing such a huge amount of resources in a transparent and efficient way will be an 
institutional  challenge.  The  public  sector’s  capacity  to  rigorously  appraise  and  effectively 
manage  its  investments  is  still  limited.  The  governance  assessment  (footnote  3)  identifies 
improvement of public expenditure management and enhancement of the capacity of local 
governments  to  plan  and  manage  the  budget  including  their  revenues,  expenditures,  and 
borrowing, as key areas requiring support. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA will assist the Government in strengthening utilization of ODA funds to support 
economic and social development needs. The expected outcome will be improved financial 
management and performance of ODA projects under the Government’s decentralization policy. 
To achieve this outcome, the TA activities will support (i) improvement of the legal framework 
and  procedures  for  financial  management  decentralization,  (ii)  improvement  of  capacity 
especially  of  local  authorities  in  financial  management  of  decentralized  ODA  projects,  (iii) 
strengthening of local government systems and capacity for managing borrowed funds, and (iv) 
enhancement  of  mobilization  and  utilization  of  less-concessional  funds6 from  development 
agencies and other sources in support of the growing public investment programs. 
 
10.   The TA will be complementary to United Nations Development Programme assistance 
for public debt management and World Bank assistance for public expenditure review. The 
proposed  TA,  focusing  on  strengthening  of  local  authorities’  capacity  for  managing  funds 
borrowed under ODA projects and programs, will also complement the TA for enhancing ODA 
absorptive capacity and efficiency that aims to help the central government agencies improve 
efficiency  in  preparation  and  implementation  of  ODA  projects  and  programs.  It could  help 
prepare for possible broader ADB support programs to strengthen public financial management 
and decentralization as ADB has done in other countries in the region such as Indonesia and 
the Philippines.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The  TA  will  help  the  Government  (i)  conduct  an  in-depth  review  and  analysis  of 
constraints  in  the  regulations,  procedures,  and  capacity  for  financial  management 
decentralization, and in the systems and capacity for managing borrowed funds; (ii) identify 
responsibilities of the parties involved in the financial management of decentralized projects; 
and (iii) define steps, measures, and time frame to improve the current regulation and system; 
and rationalize the responsibilities of relevant agencies. ADB will coordinate and synchronize 
the implementation of the proposed TA and TA for enhancing ODA absorptive capacity and 
efficiency to ensure that capacity building for the central government agencies and the local 
authorities will be consistent and complementary. The TA will undertake a series of workshops 
and seminars to disseminate the TA findings to relevant stakeholders and to achieve consensus

on recommended measures and actions. Capacity building will be an important component. 
Training  programs  will  be  conducted  for  officials  of  MOF,  relevant  ministries,  and  local 
authorities in project financial management with a focus on decentralized projects. A summary 
of the four key activities of the TA follows. 
 
12.  Assess and Improve Policies, Procedures, and Systems Related to Local Financial 
Management. The TA will support the review of current policy and procedures for local project 
financial management. This will include budget planning, expenditure control, processing of 
changes in financial allocations during project implementation, and preparation of final accounts. 
As more projects are delegated to local authorities, the existing regulations on local financial 
management may constraint efforts in project implementation. The TA will recommend ways to 
improve the current regulations and procedures. In addition, the TA will examine the institutional 
framework and capacity of local departments of finance to manage debt as selected municipal 
governments are allowed to borrow directly from development agencies and are accountable for 
the  repayment.  A  report  will  be  prepared  with  recommendations  to  improve  the  operating 
systems and staff capacity of local authorities in managing the borrowed funds, including proper 
recording and accounting, management of associated risks, and planning for repayments in the 
budgeting  process.  Consultation  workshops  will  be  organized  to  discuss  the  issues  and 
suggestions in the reports. The TA will also support incorporating the recommendations in the 
revision of relevant regulations if required.  
 
13.  Train and Build Capacity of Line Ministries and Local Governments in Project 
Financial  Management.  The  Government  has  issued  Decree  131/2006/ND-CP  on  ODA 
Management and Utilization as well as the implementing guidelines on financial management of 
ODA projects. Such regulations allow greater delegation of authority in ODA project preparation 
and management with a view to facilitating project implementation and ODA fund disbursement. 
The guidelines on financial management cover areas such as budget planning, disbursement of 
funds, and project accounting. The TA will support the training of staff of MOF, line ministries, 
local departments of finance, and project management units on policies and skills for project 
financial management, especially for decentralized projects. The training courses will cover 
financial  planning,  disbursement,  project  accounting  and  auditing,  preparation  of  the  final 
account, project asset management, and taxation issues. MOF will consult with line ministries 
and local authorities to define the training needs. Local staff will be the target participants of 
such training courses. Resource speakers/trainers will be engaged to conduct the training. The 
trainers could be experienced staff of the State Treasury, Academy of Finance, Accounting 
Association or Accounting Policy Department, and MOF’s State Budget Department. 
 
14.  Improve Mobilization and Utilization of Less-Concessional Funding Sources. With 
rapid  economic  growth,  the  financial  need  of  the  Government  to  develop  infrastructure  is 
significantly increasing. In addition to traditional concessional ODA resources, the Government 
is tapping less-concessional funding sources from development agencies. The Government 
adopted the principle that commercial loans and less-concessional loans should only be used 
for  revenue  generating  sectors  and  projects.  MOF  was  assigned  to  study  and  prepare 
guidelines for mobilizing and utilizing less-concessional funding sources, taking into account 
debt service sustainability and investment needs. The TA will support MOF to prepare such a 
report. A study visit will be organized for MOF officials to study the experience of relevant 
countries in local financial management and utilization of less-concessional funding sources. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing

5 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000. ADB will finance the equivalent of 
$400,000 on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will provide 
$100,000 equivalent, mainly in kind, covering remuneration of counterpart staff, provision of 
office accommodation, administrative and logistic support, and local travel. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  MOF will be the Executing Agency. A vice minister of MOF will be the TA director, 
providing overall guidance for implementation. MOF will assign the director of the External 
Finance Department as the deputy director of the TA. The External Finance Department will act 
as the focal point for coordinating TA activities. A working group will be established to work with 
the TA consultants to implement the TA. The group will comprise officials from the External 
Finance  Department,  State  Budget  Department,  Treasury  Department,  Accounting  Policy 
Department,  General  Department  of  Taxation,  Asset  Management  Department,  Investment 
Department, Administrative Financial Management Department, and selected local departments 
of finance. To facilitate smooth TA implementation, the working group will meet on a quarterly 
basis or as required to monitor TA implementation progress and ensure the TA objectives are 
achieved. ADB will be invited to the meetings. The TA will be implemented over 24 months, 
from March 2008 to March 2010. 
 
17.  The international public financial management specialist (4 person-months) will act as 
the TA team  leader. The  consultant  will  support  MOF  and  local  authorities to  review  and 
improve  their  system  and  capacity  to  manage  their  foreign  borrowing.  An  international 
economist will be engaged for 3 person-months to help MOF prepare guidelines for mobilizing 
less-concessional funds to support the country’s growing infrastructure needs. Two national 
consultants will be recruited to undertake the tasks defined in the terms of reference and 
support the international consultants and MOF for a total of 15 person-months. The outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be recruited on an 
individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). Several workshops and training courses will be organized to discuss the TA 
findings and to train staff involved in the financial management of ODA projects. A study visit will 
be organized for the staff of MOF and relevant ministries to study the experience of a relevant 
country  in  managing  and  utilizing  less-concessional funding  sources. The  team  leader  will 
advise MOF on the selection of the country for the study visit. Procurement of equipment for the 
TA will be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The equipment will be transferred to MOF upon TA completion. 
 
18.  The consultants will prepare and submit the following reports and documents to MOF (in 
English and Vietnamese) and ADB (in English): (i) an inception report after 1 month of fieldwork; 
(ii) interim progress reports; and (iii) draft and final completion reports upon completion of the 
TA, covering implementation and impact of TA activities. ADB will conduct inception or review 
missions  during  each  phase  of the TA  and  participate  in tripartite meetings  (Government, 
consultants, ADB) to review TA progress.

10  Appendix 3           
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   International Consultants 
 
1.  International Public Financial Management Specialist and Team Leader (4 person-
months). The specialist will report to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB); provide regular work reports as may be required by MOF in addition to those set 
forth in para.16 of the technical assistance (TA) report; and observe regulations and policies of 
the Government, particularly those of MOF. He/she will be supported by the national public 
financial management expert. Tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Review the current policies and regulations on public financial management including 
those  related  to  project  financial  management  ranging  from  financial  planning, 
expenditure  control,  budget  reallocation,  preparation  of  the  final  account,  and 
onlending. 
 
(ii)  Review the current framework and procedures for local debt management, identify 
issues and constraints in current policies and regulations, and recommend ways to 
improve the regulations. 
 
(iii)  Review  the  operating  system  of  local  departments  of  finance  and  other  related 
departments, and the capacity of local staff involved in project financial management 
and management of foreign-borrowed funds at selected cities (Hanoi and Ho Chi 
Minh). Review the current procedure for mobilizing funds, recording and monitoring 
the debt, managing related risks, and planning repayment within the overall budgeting 
framework.  Examine  the  information  technology  system  including  software  and 
hardware.  
 
(iv)  Prepare an assessment report on the regulatory framework and institutional capacity 
with  recommendations  on  improving  project  financial  management  and  foreign 
borrowing management by local authorities.  
 
(v)  Organize consultation workshops to discuss the findings and recommendations. The 
workshop  should  involve  officials  from  relevant  local  departments,  people’s 
committees, and MOF. Incorporate comments from the workshops in the assessment 
report.   
 
(vi)  Conduct training for staff of the local departments of finance and other relevant 
government agencies on project financial management including proper accounting 
and recording, management of associated risks, and planning repayment, etc.  
 
(vii)  Prepare  periodic  reports  to  ADB  and  MOF  on  implementation  progress  of  TA 
activities.  
 
(viii)  Provide national consultants with guidelines for the collection of data and documents 
and supporting activities. 
 
2.  International Economist (3 person-months). The economist should have experience 
with debt analysis and financing of public investment programs. Working in collaboration with 
the team leader and reporting to MOF and ADB, the economist will review regulations and

policies of the Government, particularly those of MOF. He/she will be supported by the national 
economist. Tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Review the current report on public debt sustainability analysis produced under the 
United Nations Development Programme-funded TA on public debt management.  
 
(ii)  Review the public investment program and sectoral infrastructure development plan 
of  the  Government  covering  transportation,  energy,  urban  infrastructure,  water 
resources, etc. 
 
(iii)  Provide  experience  and  make  recommends  on  the  use  of  less-concessional 
financing  from  bilateral  and  multilateral  development  agencies.  Support  MOF  in 
preparing guidance on the financial aspects of the use of funding. 
 
(iv)  Prepare a report with recommendations to improve mobilization and utilization of 
less-concessional funds to finance the growing infrastructure needs of the country. 
The report will take into account the debt sustainability analysis and the infrastructure 
development plan in the public investment program. It will also define the principles 
and criteria for utilizing such funding sources. 
 
(v)  Organize workshops to discuss the strategy with various departments within MOF, 
Ministry of Planning and Investment, and other relevant ministries.  
 
(vi)  Guide the national economist in collecting data and documents, and undertaking 
administrative activities. 
 
B.   National Consultants 
 
3.  National  Public  Financial Management  Expert  (10 person-months).The consultant 
should  have  a  strong  background  and  experience  in  public  finance  and  ODA  financial 
management decentralization. He/she will support and report to the international public financial 
management specialist, and support coordination with relevant departments of MOF and local 
departments of finance. Tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Collect and support the review of current policies and regulations on local financial 
management and debt management, and onlending regulations. 
 
(ii)  Review  the  current  regulations  and  procedures  on  local  project  financial 
management and prepare an assessment reports; identify the constraints. 
 
(iii)  Provide inputs in the review process of such policies and regulations, and suggest 
revisions from a local perspective.
